record:
ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: The patient, a middle-aged man and freelance landscaper presenting with symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and recurrent abdominal pain, was diagnosed with a preliminary diagnosis of gastrointestinal stromal tumor following a combination of physical examination and radiological scans, primarily MRI abdomen.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The sixty-two-year-old patient had experienced a prolonged history of abdominal pain and loss of weight over the past eight months. The patient reported difficulty completing tasks due to chronic back and abdominal muscle strain. Despite multiple evaluations by the primary care provider and some non-specific treatment for presumed diverticulitis based on initial colonoscopy, which did not demonstrate significant mucosal disease, the patient experienced worsening of overall health and persistent symptoms without any notable improvement.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Significant past medical history includes essential hypertension that is well controlled with a low dose ACE inhibitor, hyperlipidemia well managed with pravastatin, and osteoarthritis in both knees with ibuprofen use on an as needed basis for flare control.

SOCIAL HISTORY: The sixty-two-year-old patient continues to maintain active participation in his gardening-related community. As a retiree living independently, patient denies smoking but does report having an ongoing struggle with chronic daily coffee and occasional alcohol intake. A strong support system, including children and grandchildren living in a multigenerational dwelling, contributes favorably to stress management and daily living requirements.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: During examination, mild diffuse lower abdominal tenderness was noted on gentle yet comprehensive assessment of tender abdomen upon pressure or palpation, and a mass in left abdominal was appreciated deep into left lower abdominal tenderness quadrant, consistent with patient complaint location and symptom onset and worsening progression pattern reported since the onset approximately nine month period. Vital signs at the time of assessment demonstrated low range but generally relatively unremarkable hemodynamic parameters without significant distress or instability on visual, inspection and interview basis upon the current admission event.

LABORATORY DATA: Unexpected thrombocytosis in complete blood count of sixty-two-year old landscaping male the thrombocytosis revealed elevated total white blood, with subsequent further analysis confirming that sixty two-year man underwent ultrasound abdomen revealing incidental noted multiple simple small renal cyst bilateral renal units and an additional left large simple hepatic cyst and mild splenic enlargement, prompting computed tomography of whole abdominal pelvis and then subsequent diagnostic endoscopic ultrasound fine-needle aspiration.

HOSPITAL COURSE: Hospital care consisted of stabilization, management of discomfort and diagnostic evaluations and multidisciplinary involvement with medical, general abdominal and gastrointestinal specialist surgical team discussion.
nl_query: Is there an occurrence of a patient undergoing a diagnostic procedure with an unexpected result?

record:
A seventy-two year old retired chemistry teacher was admitted to the hospital with worsening dyspnea over the past week. Upon admission the diagnosis provided was of congestive heart failure. 
The patient has noted symptoms of increasing fatigue, lower extremity edema and worsening exertional dyspnea over the course of the last six months that culminated in a syncopal episode which finally prompted emergency department visit. She denied experiencing chest pain, palpitations and orthopnea.
A complex past medical history exists for the patient that include long standing hypertension, osteoporosis status post a recent vertebral compression fracture and also atrial fibrillation that has required two separate cardioversions. Medications at the time of admission include a statin, warfarin and metformin for uncontrolled new-onset diabetes mellitus diagnosed three months prior.
A pack per day cigarette smoker until she quit ten years prior the patient's personal history also includes a prior diagnosis of breast cancer at which time she received left breast lumpectomy with chemoradiation twenty years ago with surveillance mammograms negative for any disease recurrence.
A thorough exam on presentation to hospital has revealed an obese female in moderate respiratory distress at the rate of twelve to fifteen shallow breath cycles a minute on room air pulse was one forty. BP was seventy four over forty on the left and repeat exam shows sixty eight pulse ninety eight right. Cardiorespiratory shows ronchi noted bilaterally on lung fields which worsened to bibasilar rales. Cardiac has irregular pulse a two plus nonradiating precordial murmur. A comprehensive two dimensional diagnostic echocardiogram with doppler was performed. 
The patient shows significantly poor systolic left ventricular performance. Blood tests at time point reveal troponin elevation indicative myocardial necrosis occurring in addition a serum creatinine elevated by chronic standards.
While in our hospital, cardiology consultation assisted admission day medications including initiation iv cardiology approved medication for rate and a significant titration up to maximize dose on day seven prior to safe transfer out for inpatient rehab on optimized medical regimen. Despite significant improvements echocardiography results and in all clinical indices after day five were unfortunately followed by acute hospital transfer on hospital day eight post admission.
nl_query: Is there an occurrence of a patient undergoing a diagnostic procedure that yielded an unexpected result?
